data.title: Forking projects
data.description: How to fork other users projects
data.body:
Forking a Public project

Public projects on share.haiku.ai can be forked by:

  • Clicking the [Fork] button under any project in the Showcase.

  • Clicking the [Fork] button in the project's detail.

  • Right clicking a project and selecting [Fork].

Forks are a unique copy of a project, which can be freely experimented on without affecting the original projects. Forks can be a fun and interesting way to build upon other people's work, using their project as a starting point for your own idea.

Support for this feature was implemented in Animator (previously Haiku for Mac) v3.1.19, released mid March 2018. If you created your account before this, you may need to run the app once from your Applications folder before forking a project on share.haiku.ai.

Forking a Private project

The ability to fork private projects is under development, and should be shipped soon, though we don't have an exact date.

A workaround for forking private projects using Git that you could try is:

Clone projects into your user's project directory, remove the .git directory, and create a project with the same name. 

The remote URL in your projects on disk contains your GitLab credentials, so you can get the correct secure clone URL. 

It requires some command line comfort.

data.title: Rotations behaving unpredictably
data.description: Animator uses radians, not degrees, which can cause rotations to behave unexpectedly
data.body: Rotations in Animator are based on radians, not degrees. In the future, you'll be able to use both radians and degrees for rotation input, but for now you can use a degrees to radian calculator.

data.title: Troubleshooting: Text elements cropped at the bottom
data.description: What should I do if my texts are cropped?
data.body: If your text elements are cropped at the bottom, ensure that your line height is the same or greater than the character size in Sketch.

data.title: Does Animator support WPF?
data.description: Using Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF) via React Native
data.body: To our knowledge, yes, though we haven't tried ourselves. As Animator supports Lottie, you can use Lottie React Native —> React Native Windows, which is reported to support WPF.

data.title: Using consistent transform sizes on elements of varying size
data.description: Work with different sized elements easier
data.body:
If you want to use different sized elements in Animator with consistent transform sizes, one way to do that is to use artboards in Sketch instead of slices.

In the example above, you can see Sketch artboards on the left with consistent dimensions. When they're instantiated in the stage in Animator, they have consistent transform sizes making it easier to manipulate them with the desired effect.

data.title: Who owns projects made in Animator?
data.description: Legal implications of content made in Animator
data.body: This is covered in our Terms of service in the bottom paragraph. You own your designs — we don't.

data.title: Can I rely on Animator to keep my projects around forever?
data.description: Where your projects live, and how to access their raw data and manage with git
data.body:
You don't have to! Your designs live on your computer — they're all inside the ~/.haiku folder (you can type open ~/.haiku in terminal to open that folder in Finder).

Animator is built on top of Git, and just like code, it all just sits in files and folders on your computer — it only ever goes to our servers when you publish. When you Publish, you're just triggering a git push behind the scenes.

This means that you don't need Animator at all to have on-going control of your animations. We believe your work should be yours and we don't buy into the 'walled garden' approach to design and developer tools.

data.title: How much does Animator cost?
data.description: Do you have different pricing plans?
data.body:
Animator currently has three plans to offer:

  • Starter: 14-day free trial.

  • Animator Pro: All the features and offline mode.

  • Teams: Bulk licensing.

Learn more

data.title: Using Custom Fonts
data.description: How to use custom fonts in Animator
data.body:
When viewing your published animation on share.haiku.ai your browser may render text elements using default system fonts. To use custom fonts, ensure that your Sketch source file is referencing the same custom font name that's embedded in your website or app.

Alternatively, you can also right click a text element in Sketch and use 'Convert to Outlines' to convert your text element to a vector shape.
